para.paratext: Impeachment is the process by which a witness' veracity is questioned on cross-examination. Georgia law changed in 2005 to allow any party, including the party calling the witness, to attack that witness' credibility.[1] This brought Georgia in line with federal practice, and now O.C.G.A. § 24-6-607 and Fed. R. Evid. 607 are identical. A witness cannot be impeached prior to his testimony.[2]

The methods of impeachment set out in the Official Code of Georgia are not exclusive.[3] A party may introduce any evidence which may, in the slightest degree, affect the credibility of a witness.[4] A witness is usually impeached by the introduction of evidence outside the substance of his testimony.

For example, information used in a competency evaluation may be used to attack the credibility of a witness found to be competent. In Ballard v. Meyers,[5] the Georgia Supreme Court held that a witness could be impeached with a document which the offering party had not disclosed in his pretrial order because it is impossible to know prior to trial what witnesses will say and what impeachment evidence will be relevant. Even evidence which violates the constitutional standard of due process, such as an unlawfully obtained confession, may be admitted for impeachment purposes.[6]

In Georgia, the introduction of evidence of a felony conviction is a general attack on the credibility of that witness. “The introduction of evidence of a prior felony conviction is intended to afford the jury a basis to infer that the witness's character is such that he would be less likely than the average trustworthy citizen to be truthful in his testimony.” Smith v. State, 331 Ga. App. 296, 771 S.E.2d 8 (2015). However, evidence of a conviction more than 10 years' old is limited by O.C.G.A. § 24-6-609(b). Moreover, a first offender plea may not be used to impeach on general credibility grounds because first offender status is not considered an adjudication of guilt. O.C.G.A. § 24-6-609(c); Rivers v. State, 296 Ga. 396, 768 S.E.2d 486 (2015). First offender may be used to demonstrate bias or motive to testify in favor of the state while the offender remains under that sentence. Crapps v. State, 329 Ga. App. 820, 766 S.E.2d 178 (2014).

Another way to impeach a witness is through contradictory testimony, which does not require a foundation.[7] Discrepancy regarding an immaterial matter may not be used to impeach a witness[8] unless the witness raises the issue himself on direct examination.

In a medical malpractice case, Richards v. Harpe,[9] the defendant physician testified on direct examination that he “had never experienced any trouble in reducing broken bones.” Although the defendant's treatment of other patients was immaterial to the case, the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the plaintiff's lawyer should have been allowed to cross-examine the defendant regarding specific problems which had arisen when he treated other patients with broken bones.

In another medical malpractice case, Weaver v. Ross,[10] the court allowed a plaintiff to cross-examine a defendant physician about falsifying another patient's records because the defendant had testified on direct examination that she had not done so. On cross examination, the defendant physician denied falsifying the record of another patient. The trial court properly allowed another witness to testify that the physician had, in fact, falsified the records of the other patient. In upholding the lower court's admission of this impeachment testimony, the Georgia Court of Appeals cited Richards and stated that the rules of evidence should not be construed “to provide a safe haven for witnesses to voluntarily give false or misleading testimony in court.” The court also noted that the subject of falsifying records had been raised during the physician's direct examination and that the denial of falsification on cross-examination would have corroborated defendant's direct testimony if left unrebutted.

In Hollis v. State,[11] the court allowed cross-examination of a criminal defendant's character witness about the defendant's plea of nolo contendere to a previous charge because the witness testified on direct examination that defendant was not charged for the previous crime. However, in another case, a witness could not be impeached with a conviction which occurred in one jurisdiction but was being used as a similar offense in a second jurisdiction where the trial court believed the conviction was from the second jurisdiction.[12]

A witness may be impeached regarding discrepancy over a collateral issue which is indirectly material to the issue in the case.[13] However, an attorney may not impeach a witness with a document prepared by another witness.[14]

A cross-examiner cannot elicit testimony from a witness and then attempt to impeach using inadmissible evidence. Also, evidence of a criminal defendant's bad character is not admissible when a criminal defendant makes a statement during his testimony that does not put his character in issue.[15] However, evidence to contradict his statement is admissible even though it might tend to show bad character.[16]

For example, in Jackson v. State,[17] the jury was allowed to watch and listen to a video showing the defendant selling cocaine. Approximately 30 seconds after the transaction concluded, the informant on the tape referred to the defendant as “the one that shot Freak Nasty in the stomach.” Defense counsel failed to object to that portion of the tape. Defendant was convicted of selling cocaine. The Court of Appeals held there was no error since the statement did not contribute to a guilty verdict. The court reasoned that the jury was provided with substantial evidence at trial of defendant's guilt, and the statement referred to a violent crime and not the sale of cocaine.

Moreover, in Williams v. State,[18] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the state improperly impeached by contradiction by admitting two prior juvenile arrests of defendant after defendant testified that he had never been in trouble.

Also, in State v. Rocco,[19] the Georgia Supreme Court overturned a conviction because the prosecutor elicited cross-examination testimony from defendant that he did not drive drunk, then introduced evidence that the defendant had previously pled nolo contendere to a DUI charge.
In Davis v. Stewart, 169 Ga. App. 733, 315 S.E.2d 6 (1984), the court excluded plaintiff's proffer of defendant's prior conviction because the defendant had not yet testified.
Sheffield v. Hammond, 41 Ga. App. 76, 151 S.E. 663 (1930); Lewis v. American Road Ins. Co., 119 Ga. App. 507, 167 S.E.2d 729 (1969).
McGriff v. McGriff, 152 Ga. 560, 115 S.E. 21 (1922); Walraven v. Walraven, 76 Ga. App. 713, 47 S.E.2d 148 (1948).

Ballard v. Meyers, 275 Ga. 819, 821, 572 S.E.2d 572 (2002). The court exempted impeachment evidence from the language of Sup. Ct. R. 7.2(14) which requires parties to “list all documentary and physical evidence that will be tendered at trial.”
Charlton v. State, 217 Ga. App. 842, 459 S.E.2d 455 (1995). See also Campbell v. State, 215 Ga. App. 14, 449 S.E.2d 366 (1994).

In Carson v. State, 192 Ga. App. 52, 383 S.E.2d 619 (1989), defendant sought to introduce evidence that a rape victim had been fired from her job rather than quitting as she had testified. The Georgia Court of Appeals stated, “Whether the victim had (quit or been fired from several jobs) is wholly immaterial to the issue of (appellant's guilt of the (crime) charged.”
Richards v. Harpe, 42 Ga. App. 123, 155 S.E. 85 (1930).
Weaver v. Ross, 192 Ga. App. 568, 386 S.E.2d 43 (1989).
Hollis v. State, 191 Ga. App. 525, 382 S.E.2d 145 (1989).
Robinson v. State, 332 Ga. App. 240, 771 S.E.2d 751 (2015).
Barngrover v. Hins, 289 Ga. App. 410, 657 S.E.2d 14 (2008).
Merritt v. State, 329 Ga. App. 871, 766 S.E.2d 217 (2014).
Cooper v. State, 272 Ga. App. 209, 612 S.E.2d 42 (2005).
Jackson v. State, 321 Ga. App. 607, 739 S.E.2d 86 (2013).
Williams v. State, 257 Ga. 761, 363 S.E.2d 535 (1988).
